column8: I had a chance to check Google on campus at my community college today - checked "revenge pornography" and got over 820,000 hits.  My sense is that we're not all that restricted here.

column7: we would challenge developers to ask themselves
column8: We talk about digital literacy for our students, but I think as faculty, we are also suffering from a lack of D.L. which makes us unable to ask the right critical questions about EdTech.  Two examples: my uni recently purchased a new system that will help us manage data for accreditation processes. The dean was very excited that the system came with a free ePortfolio tool. How great to save money by getting it free with something we had to buy anyway! But of course, this ePortfolio tool is totally wrapped into and serving the accreditation process, which is really different than the kind of learner-controlled ePortfolios we were talking about initiating.  Most fac and staff on the tech committee didn't know anything about the ethics of big data or how data is used by/for/against students, so we were really vulnerable to being sold a product by an EdTech company who knew exactly what we didn't really understand.  Another example: our Student Success™ coaches are a bought-and-paid-for predictive analytics algorithm.  Say what you will about that, most of our faculty don't even KNOW this.  They think it's "personalized advising." It's hard to talk about the pros and cons of the collection of this data or the use of these predictive models with colleagues when the EdTech companies obscure their methods in the language of student-centered pedagogies.  So much to love in this article, and I know I am just taking a tiny nugget here and going in a different direction, but just thinking about how to begin to talk about these issues with my colleagues, and realizing the digital literacy issue is a really significant hurdle.

Following the first Marginal Syllabus flash mob on Wednesday, August 31st (reflection [here](http://marginalsyllab.us/flash-mob/reflecting-on-marginal-syllabus-first-flash-mob/)), a few folks participated in this Google Hangout: https://youtu.be/DRW-b3RlOnM

I was just researching a bunch of this stuff, since my uni has signed up with (ie- purchased) Student Success™ coaches, using a predictive advising algorithm.  Anyway, as far as I can tell, we aren't using anything like this, but I found this code for ethical practice which I quite like: https://www.jisc.ac.uk/guides/code-of-practice-for-learning-analytics. Thought others might be interested, too.

While analytics and tracking are obviously different activities than filtering, they are connected and mutually supportive. Understanding how they work together is a critical element to interrogating and pushing back against uses that disempower individuals. Give the widespread use (and opacity of that use) of tracking and analytics to power filtering, the onus is on people who want to use these technologies to demonstrate that they can use them responsibly.

One of the things my institution does--you can call and have something unblocked, but this does cut into the learning a bit because it's disruptive. Often you only see that something is blocked in the moment you need it.

This is a really important point. I am growing increasingly uncomfortable with the ways students are tracked. It sounds like you have given a lot of thought to how your institution does this, but there are many out there who just assume they know "what's best" for the student in regards to this.

It is a thorny issue. K-12 filtering is federally mandated, although the level of that filtering is typically left up to individual districts. In my experience, content filtering dose happen in higher ed (as we discuss in the essay), but it's a bit less common.

I'm not sure any exist at this time. I'm actually interested in doing a crowdsourced project that might show what diff results show up at different institutions. There are some slight variations that you could get by using a VPN and changing your location.

column7: it isn't recognized as a problem at community colleges
column8: This question is asked purely out of ignorance in that I don't know if this is true at all or not: could it be that many people don't recognize it's happening, even at the faculty level? I admit to not having known this was a problem at any postsecondary institution, but maybe that's b/c I work at an "R1" institution. I didn't know it was happening at CC's, or elsewhere. Indeed, it might even be happening at my campus and I don't even know.  But perhaps the question is: for those who DO know about it, why is it not seen as a problem? Then the answers given here apply. But I wonder how many faculty and students are aware?
Please do--that would be wonderful.

I'm curious as to the justification given for not being able to download anything w/o justifying to IT first. I honestly am having trouble seeing why they would restrict in this way. But I'm probably being naive!
Oh, what a great thing to do on Ok U's part. Something to mention to people in IT at my uni!

I agree with the consent issue especially. Do students know they are being tracked, and do they have the option to opt out? That is important. In the FT article, in one of the pilots students could sign up to have their information connected to them personally (rather than just being collected in aggregate form). Then, even if they are given the option to consent, they need to know exactly what data is being collected, who has access to it, how long it will be kept, security measures to keep it private, etc. Will they be able to get the data out of the system if they request it at any time? Will the data be given to another institution later, if they transfer?  My university has a different version of this: we are encouraged to submit an "early alert" report on students who stop coming to class or are failing or are showing worrisome signs of mental distress (e.g., students who say they are considering suicide). I always tell students if I'm going to submit such an alert, and what it means. I tell them who has access to the information and how it is used (only a few people, and only to follow up with offers of resources for help). I only use it for situations when I have tried to work with the student and they are not responding, or there is indication of imminent danger to themselves. Still, I feel a bit uncomfortable at times because they can't get their records cleared if they want, later, so far as I know. And I don't know how long the records are kept. But at least this is not following every student, all the time.
Wow, what's up with the bullseyes? But yeah, quite Foucaultian indeed! :)

Wow--this just reinforces for me, again, how publishers are not in the business of making knowledge available, but walling it off. The amount of time and money spent on making sure there are walls is enormous. Much harder than just making it available. That's what you have to do if you want to monetize knowledge. But should it be monetized at all? Big philosophical question...I think most of the time "no," but then again what about literature? Yikes, this is a hard question! Still, I hate how hard it is to access knowledge in different institutions and countries based in part of lack of money, in part on politics.

I think it may depend on the level of education? Meaning, I'm not sure that filters need to be so bad for my elementary-school-aged-son. I don't know what filters those would be, exactly, and I'm sure however we try to do it it will leave out things that are useful and important (like Cummings and Dickinson). But I really don't want him running into violent, oppressive, cruel, misogynist porn (for example). I'm not against pornography when done in a way that respects all and shows voluntariness, etc., but I'd not want him to run into the other stuff unexpectedly until he's a bit older and can think about it more carefully and understand what it is and how it's a problem. That's just one example.   So for higher ed and high school, e.g., I am not sure we should be filtering at all. For elementary school, maybe so. I don't have answers as to when it should stop, or what it should be like. It's just that I see a bit of a complication here.

I completely agree. Where can we find the information useful to show students what is being filtered and how, in various situations? The problem sometimes is that that information may be hard to get. What is the algorithm Google uses? Facebook? Other things? Sometimes these are hard to find. Anyone have any good resources for giving students concrete examples of what is filtered and how by these popular services?

I didn't know about this either. I just looked it up on Google, and I can't quite understand it. It looks like if you have it on, it shows some things like Google events or bills or flights or other things that only you can see; others wouldn't be able to see those results b/c they are private to your use of those google products. This is what I found: https://support.google.com/websearch/answer/1710607  That's a different kind of filter than what I was thinking about with this article, though.
Failing forward
But with blunt tools, can't we allow a human touch to unblock sections of it?

Oh definitely YES. Doing my PhD at a time when Egypt had political instability and I didn't have library access I used every illegal cooy of a text I could find. Even when I buy stuff on Kindle and pay I am doing a trick to be able to get it (coz so much material isn't supposed to be available to Egypt from publishers. Why???) and my belief is that if a publisher won't make it available to me legally then it's my right to find my own way. I have a selective ethics here. I never pirate music or movies but I will do for knowledge if it's not legally available via my library or Kindle. Right now Egypt has an agreement called Egyptian Knowledge Bank that gives us access to lots of stuff even if ue not affiliated with any library (more fair than before)

In this FT article http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/634624c6-312b-11e5-91ac-a5e17d9b4cff.html#slide0 one of the people interviewed really gives away the game in terms of analytics. "losing a student is expensive"

I think you're right Autumm. And as others are saying... The commercial drive behind filtering of Google; the redlining behind filtering on campuses...how and why these filters work that way and how they restrict our access to knowledge
I did NOT know that option on Google! Will check it out
Pretty sure at my institution they used to do that. Not sure of details and I probably wouldn't approve...
Google searches not filtered by institution...but governed by Google algorithms. #JustSaying

I highlight this as a good statement differentiating between digital redlining as a policy choice reproducing inequality vs digital divide (which we haven't defined in this article but I suppose implies difference in power/access without explaining values and intentionality behind how it became so?)

I'm also thinking of the implications of this for parenting and some discussions i have had w my student-teachers who believed in giving boys freedom to browse but monitoring girls' time online to "protect them"

This seems to me, Jeremy like retention on someone else's terms. That advisors and policy makers want these students to stay and end up a certain way. Versus possibly finding themselves and not completing college. I don't understand complexity of it and I understand retention is important economically and such...but I don't know that I could support something so seemingly unethical in order to get a good outcome (where "good outcome" is judged to be something specific and is value-laden). Why can't we think of ways to improve retention that are more ethical? (i don't know full story so just responding to tidbits here)

Yes! Such an important statement and applicable to different contexts as well - digital and analog. Digital social reproduction

I love when my stuff is hacked, its a learning experience and allows me to grow. To support those who "will not hack" in order to learn we need to provide opportunities for exploration without filters. I believe they will gradually want to dig deeper and potentially hack to find out more.

"How much are we all limited by this access" is one of the most important questions I can think of. And not just relative to online, but all access to information.  How do we even become aware of our limitations to information, to begin to find opportunities to surpass them?
Particularly now, as a graduate-level educator, the presence of the grade book in an LMS reinforces this idea that I'm an accountant. Ugh.
What skills and fluencies are we trying to develop?
Agreed. Because the LMS also manages grades, calendars, etc., students (and profs) experience these as part of a pedagogical design.

BMBOD - This is what brought me to be an educator in the first place, I love epistemology and wanted to spread the love to anyone who would listen. I think full blown access is needed, I wouldn't have developed the filters i have now if I had limited access. It seems we are setting students up for failure when we limit their access and filter for them. They need space to develop and explore necessary filters or once the filters are gone...who knows what they'll do.
Wow! Yes, please do!
YEP!
This is important and it highlights the needs to focus on the educational potential of the internet rather than discrete tools marketed as educational technology.

Thanks again for the opportunity to have this conversation!  It was especially great to have the author of the article on with us so we can think critically together! A great example of openly networked connected learning!
I can show you our chart!
Agreed, these are very powerful questions! And perhaps I'd add: And in promoting greater openness and access, how do our tools and processes create the conditions for greater educational equity?

I can try to verify this, but I have found suggested policies that IT department are only too happy to pick up on. That way, they don't have to write the language themselves. Much seems to come via K-12.
This is totally on point. And how behavior is coded will very much depend on who the student population is.
gah! come back!
Most importantly, the tool that ought to help teach search skills doesn't act like a real search engine.
Completely agree here, freedom of decision and choice for future. How can we support this in our institutions (both K-12 and higher ed)?

I'm wondering if you could say a bit more? My critiques of student surveillance are many, but even if they are shown to be effective at something like retention, it generally ignores consent and poses massive security risks.

column7: general failure to acknowledge that redlining was a conscious policy.
column8: There's a vicious cycle suggested here where schools with disproportionate discipline data will become consumers for filters while schools where students aren't routinely referred, suspended and expelled will become consumers for STEM programs. Michelle Alexander writes about how the new Jim Crow laws don't have racially explicit language. Instead, they have neutral language that disproportionately impacts communities of color.

I wonder if it is appropriate to have a gradual release of "protection" for students as they progress from K to 12?  Our school district uses this tool predominantly in the elementary schools for safety and other features like read aloud. It does filter content based on reading level, for example, and I wonder if teachers inhibit student growth in reading by creating a barrier to higher reading levels that may extend a student's skills?

column7: For software developers,
column8: Agree with everything above and below about interrogating the underlying pedagogies of edtech tools and software developers collaborating with teachers, etc. but are AUPs written by software developers?

I took it less as "learning 'can only happen on the school provided computer and school provided internet'" as a overarching statement, and more of we can only expect that as the minimum possibility- because of accessibility issues. So we should think about what the school/institutional provided technology offers and limits as the highest we can expect of our students (even if some can go well beyond that) because for some, that is all that is available.
bhwilkoff... self managing iPads! ;)
I believe that if the change is framed correctly and with the right evidence, these leaders will absolutely opt for change.
Absolutely! How can we better share those conversations so that they are transparent and that we can all learn from them!?
Maybe. But, I have seen many organizations use analytics to better serve their users and not find ways to better restrict.
Amen!
Absolutely.
Reflection is key for effective research.  I can take any research and add bias but reflection allows me to explore and examine my own bias to make revisions.

Yes - and this is something we need to model for our students; to find means/modes to engage with administration, policy, etc, in creative, generative, and collaborative ways.

It is important to note that Tumblr is, in fact, heavily used by non-legal porn enthusiasts. I do not believe this is a reason to block an entire site, but it is not without merit to the legality of blocking porn on Tumblr.

They're trying to do their best to provide "safe search" in a space where young children have internet access. The problem is that their tools are blunt instruments and they take their cues from a culture that often thinks the Internet is vital for adults and optional for youth.
+1 onewheeljoe I think you hit the nail on the head with "systemic racism".

yes! recognizing our own beliefs and perceptions are filters is so important.  We can't take in or process information without filtering it; we just need to work on recognizing when, how, and why we are filtering it.
Researcher bias
At my place, too few people even understand that there is filtering on. The IT dept often gives incomplete or erroneous info to faculty to make their jobs easier.

I believe you, but the actual place and the context for where this type of filtering happens really matters. Policies are put in place by people in a place. Without the people and without the place, it is very difficult to try and understand how to change the policy.

It seems counterintuitive to wall off information, especially at the higher education level.  I thought higher ed was supposed to be a place for students to shape, form, and justify their own ideas, arguments, passions, and interests without bias.  Obviously there is bias, but to also learn to see it for what it is and cut through that.

column7: Digital redlining takes place when policymakers and designers make conscious choices about what kinds of tech and education are "good enough" for certain populations but also happens through the failure to interrogate policy and design.
column8: One example in the k-12 space is Nettrekker, a safe search tool that relies so heavily on crowdsourced vetting of results that it doesn't act like a real search engine. In the name of safety, teachers provide students with an experience so protected that only the most general searches produce results.
Yeah, this is a pretty great mantra for those wanting work responsible on or with education technologies.

Excellent, and complicated question. Not just from the more concrete example here, but in the abstract... like, having access to ALL information generated can be quite detrimental, given that some of it is likely to be inappropriate (not in content but in context) and therefore there is more need for individuals to make judgement calls on the quality and relevance of the information, rather than an outside source.   I'm all for this; I'm really into personal epistemology and that's part of why. But the current state of education feels directly in contrast to this. We "wall" people off from "incorrect" information all the time...

Yes, my thought exactly!  Everything is filtered somehow. We have to understand how our own brain filters the world all the way to how information is presented to us by whom.  Critical thinking needs to be the new norm.

Yes. I'm interested in how constraints tend to produce better results for some. The issue, though, is how those who "will not hack" in order to learn. How will we support them?
http://www.theatlantic.com/education/archive/2016/04/internet-filtering-hurts-kids/479907/

column7: we would challenge developers to ask themselves
column8: Developers will always build products that people are asking for. We can't ask them to stop building filters if that is what educators and IT folks want.   We can, instead, start educating Developers as to the MUCH LARGER MARKET for products that empower learners.

column7: her advisor uses the "intrusive advising" recommended by the Guided Pathways to Success program
column8: LOL. Looks like I annotated this article with hypothes.is a while back when I was researching a talk on surveilance in edtech.   I've long been intrigued by this type of advisory surveilance after hearing a very compelling defense of its use at a conference: the claim, by the President of Georgia State, was that these programs did indeed improve retention.  In full expectation of being bombarded by dissenting comments, I'm interested in troubling the standard opposition of surveilance as applied to technology by many critical academics. (And I say this with a long love affair with Foucault et al.)   Without going to far off topic here, is it totally fair to move from the censorship of information that is the focus here to what could be at least I'd hope a more nuanced use of data to inform?

This makes me think of the government sponsored hackathons, code breaking competitions, etc.   You identify individuals that can push against the boundaries and limits, and then proposition them to make the next round of boundaries. It's a reflexive practice that perpetuates itself.
I have been there. Not only that, why are they blocking anything that's legal?

In Hanging Out Messing Around and Geeking Out, the authors indicated that low SES homes saw computer access as a way to be ready to learn job-specific software. Higher SES groups saw access as key to exploring interests and as a creative outlet. I would conclude some communities are shown more possibilities than others due to systemic racism.

column7: implicit pedagogy of any technology
column8: No technology is pedagogically agnostic. We need to stop treating them as if they were.
Thanks! Good to know!

This also makes me think about how aware we are of our own brains and the filters we consciously and unconsciously create.  Especially those based on ideology and belief; we will ignore facts if they don't fit with our mental constructs.

column7: Indeed, with filtering in place, attempts to research the limits placed on technology can be blocked, and the person asking the questions will have their searches logged. Therein lies the danger.
column8: Much like we encourage "white hat" hackers to dig into a network for vulnerabilities, perhaps we need to encourage "white hat" educators to explore our filters and look for the implications of the policies in every day practice.  How can we encourage teachers and students to "try and break things" in order to make them better?

Right. A big part of why we wrote this is having taught at other institutions, we see the very different ideas about access. Also, when college access is the main access (or only access) it matters more. That's where the redlining happens.

column7: the limits of her world are being shaped by the limits imposed on the information she can access.
column8: How much are we all limited by this access? How do we provide daily opportunities for students to surpass these limits?

Here's a way that is tedious, but legit (other than interlibrary loan of course):   You can register for free individual access to JSTOR to access other subject areas.  See http://about.jstor.org/individuals     The program allows individual users to have online access (i.e. no downloads!) to 3 articles every 2 weeks.   Since “individual access” accounts are restricted to 3 articles every 14 days, you may want to search outside of JSTOR to identify items that are the most interesting to you.  <-- That's not even subversive!  Just sort of annoying  but definitely do-able!  :)

column7: The comfortable elision in "edtech" is dangerous; it needs to be undone by emphasizing the contexts, origins, aims, and ideologies of technologies.

I think that is an excellent question
I wonder how filtering differently may inhibit equitable access for students to information

So, could the problem be not so much the filter itself as the illusion that there is no filter? If you don't understand that there are filters and if you don't understand what filters there are then you are prime for manipulation.

column7: codified in institutions' acceptable use policies.
column8: I would love to see the acceptable use policies and question the people behind them. I do believe that the solution here is much more of a people/understanding one and not one that is inherently about technology. How is it that we can ask questions of those administrators and IT professionals rather than railing against the policy in a vacuum.
I certainly didn't mean to imply that!

column7: Her college's acceptable-use policy is likely to exclude her from P2P services.
column8: I've heard IT people determine that Tumblr is a porn site. In the instance in my memory, their only view of Tumblr was the one a filtering software gave them. It presented them a view of the blog platform that highlighted only inappropriate posts.  As I asked for access to a Tumblr post related to academics, I noted that the person I was appealing to thought I wanted porn unblocked for schools. I just wanted to read an academic's informal reflections.

Agree, conversation opportunities for students about filters are important aspects of their growth as humans.  They need the space to explore filters and their necessity only insomuch as they are self imposed.

column7: It is a different thing, a set of education policies, investment decisions, and IT practices that actively create and maintain class boundaries through strictures that discriminate against specific groups.
column8: Highlighted this in response to Jeremy's comment above about filters. Institutional practices and policies are the focus here as well as the physical infrastructure for IT, available equipment.
There's issues with those as well though--limited data plans, no access to wifi, sites that aren't optimized for mobile. It's a big problem in some communities--especially rural and inner city.

I hope not!   The way I see it is there are two possibilities. Students will either abandon the search, or "hack" the system and find a way to make it do what they want.   As an instructional designer, I'm happy if anything I create is "hacked" to make it more usable but I also want to design things that don't feel like they need to be "hacked" in order to make them usable at all.

I'd suggest by opening up conversations about the web as something that is not a given, not natural, but a designed artifact (a set of systems) that - because they were created by people with biases - reflect human biases.

column7: The modern filter not only limits access to knowledge, but it also tracks when people knock against these limits. In this environment, curiosity looks a lot like transgression.
column8: I think it may be important to ask whether analytics and tracking are the same as filtering. While I would argue against both in some cases, the knowledge of the interest of your patrons/users may in fact create better policies and not worse.
Great question, and this is where I suspect - in some cases - fear dictates policy, and a lack of consensus is not a primary concern.

column7: The instructor has predetermined processes and goals
column8: This article implies that all community college instructors are sheep who only care about workforce training.  That has been my experience.
I think it's imperative that we do, because if we don't, students often move on thinking that either the info doesn't exist or that it's not important enough to seek out.

column7: Twenty years ago, before the "black boxes" became invisible and silent, buzzers alerted us when someone pushed against a boundary. We try to reassure ourselves that today, the road to information has become clearer, unencumbered by bells, whistles, or buzzers.
column8: There is such an important distinction here; what was public--and shaming--was at least apparent. Now it is implicit, and with that people aren't even aware its occurring. We may think our world is expanded and complete without being aware of how narrow we are allowed to see (feeling very Truman Show?)  Do we as educators make that boundary more clear? Do we embrace the invisible boundaries and teach our students to push back at everything, seeking out those invisible barriers and rail against them?
Exactly!

column7: computer labs
column8: Here I start wondering about the politics between IT, academic departments, and the library. Could a campus computer lab have different filter settings on a general computer lab, a discipline specific computer lab, and the computer lab in the library

column7: where digital resources are scarce
column8: I believe this is likely a false scarcity in many cases. We only consider computers to be learning tools. Mobile devices that many of our students carry, can also be used for these purposes. There are far fewer filters on these types of devices, and when folks opt for them rather than those with filters on, there is much more incentive to move toward a less filtered experience on the "official devices for learning".

Of course. So we can make the case that we are digitally manipulated. But is every filter a red line? Don't want to get off track here, but I think there are distinctions. This article addresses redlining at the institutional level.
I assure you that the only things made up in this essay are the names. All real events.
Yes, please share those results either back here or via Twitter using #marginalsyllabus
Yep, there are lots of ways around, some of them not exactly *legit* Can we/should we let our students know about these things? (I think yes).
yeah, it makes me think about the prevalence of "echo chambers" and our awareness of being in one or not...

Our google searches are not filtered and we have databases where revenge porn would show up. I think part of the issue here is that redlining takes on so many different forms, unique to each institution, and this enables its invisibility.

column7: abandons that search

column7: Internet is filtered

I would love to hear about the results. I'm working on a project that looks at how different college filters and access turn up different search results!
+1 Remi, right there with you.

column7: Because the filters between her and the Internet block access to information,
column8: Not to derail this great discussion, but Isn't the Internet already a filter? We need to teach students that even Google is always already filtered...

column7: the buzzer continues to blare so everyone can see her walk of shame
column8: I would love to hear about the experiences from real students in this environment and the policies that allow for this kind of shaming. This seems more like hyperbole than a story of how real people think that policies should be enforced.
I immediately thought about surveillance...

column7: "black boxes"
column8: BTW, if you are interested in privacy, and haven't read Frank Pasqaule's Black Box Society, you should!
Yes, awesome, thanks Chris!

column7: a buzzer
column8: I'm interested in whether we see these buzzers as a support for human interaction and conversation or as a way to circumvent it.

Full-text not available on JSTOR means that your institution couldn't afford to license everything. How about Interlibrary Loan?  That is a service that can be used to fill in gaps in library collections.  *Errg - I have some info on a way to get some resources out of JSTOR even if your library doesn't have full text of all of it. There's also a great way to make use of Google Scholar to find a lot of research that is open access... Can your librarians at your institutions help you overcome what you see as deficits in your library collections?  I vote yes!
A special thanks to Chris Gilliard (hypervisible) for joining the first Marginal Syllabus flash mob and talking with us about these important educational equity issues.

column7: revenge porn
column8: I am a community college librarian. I just checked and there are 784 items on revenge porn available via the library.  I'm not on campus right now - but I will be sure to check what happens with a Google search next time I'm at work.

column7: reinforce restrictive pedagogies.
column8: Yes: last AY, all administrative control was removed from our laptops. Faculty cannot download any software without justifying it to IT first. Cannot, e.g. download Gephi or Twine, and programminghistorian.org simply says "site unavailable."

column7: Because she's a community college student, it's likely that she is hemmed in by many invisible boundaries. When she uses journal storage (through JSTOR), she is probably using one of its smaller versions that offer far fewer journals.
column8: This is so very true where I work (CC), though in our system, our students and faculty can often see what they are not allowed to access: full text not available. But entire important databases are not available to our students and they don't know it, along with the missing larger JSTOR et al.

column7: Because the filters between her and the Internet block access to information, she reasonably believes that the issue is marginal and that other topics might prove more fruitful. She moves on to something else, unaware of the invisible walls erected that prevent her from accessing information that might allow her to do her I am work. The student has been digitally redlined, walled off from information based on the IT policies of her institution.
column8: So so helpful to explain it this way
